data.title: James Walter Milles Stopford (1853-1933)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Explore genealogy for James Stopford born 1853 Marylebone, London, England, United Kingdom died 1933 St George Hanover Square, London, England, United Kingdom including ancestors + descendants + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors Descendants

Profile last modified 5 May 2023 | Created 28 Aug 2019

This page has been accessed 454 times.

James Stopford was a member of the aristocracy in British Isles.

Contents

1 Biography

2 Birth

3 Education

4 Marriages

5 Titles

6 Public Office

7 Death

8 Sources

Biography

Birth

He was born to the parents of the Hon. Elizabeth Frances Milles and James George Henry Stopford, 5th Earl of Courtown.[1] He was born on the 3rd of March 1853 at Marylebone, London, England.[1][2]

Education

He attended Eton College, Windsor, Berkshire, England between 1866 and 1871[1][3] He attended Trinity College, Cambridge University, Cambridge, Cambridgeshire, England.[1]

Marriages

He was married twice, firstly to the Hon. Catherine Elizabeth Neville, daughter of the Lady Charlotte Sarah Graham-Toler and Richard Cornwallis Neville, 4th Lord Braybrooke, Baron of Braybrooke, on the 27th of April 1876 at St. George's Church, St. George Street, Hanover Square, London, England.[1][4] He married, secondly, Gertrude Mills, daughter of Gertrude Whitbread and General Charles James Conway Mills, on the 25th of September 1886 at St. Paul's Church, Knightsbridge, London, England[1][5]

Titles

6th Earl of Courtown, co. Wexford [I., 1762] on 28 November 1914.[3]

5th Baron Saltersford, of Saltersford, co. Chester [G.B., 1796] on 28 November 1914.[3]

6th Baron Courtown, co. Wexford [I., 1758] on 28 November 1914.[3]

6th Viscount Stopford [I., 1762] on 28 November 1914.[3]

Public Office

Sheriff of County Wexford in 1877.[1]

Sheriff of County Carlow in 1878.[1]

Aide-de-Camp to the Lord-Lieutenant of Ireland, Earl of Carnarvon.[1]

Office of Lord-Lieutenant of County Wexford on 27 July 1901.[1]

Death

He died at the age of 80 on the 18th of July 1933 at 7 Chesham Place, London, England.[3][6] He was buried on the 21st of July 1933 at City of Westminster Cemetery, Hanwell, London, England[3][7]

Sources
